flow.descriptionCdata:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.08ecc105-b7b8-4594-ab1e-ae5567b606cd.prompt=HostName\: 2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.0a763235-4727-48ca-a875-e947ff5b281f.prompt=UserName\: 2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.10df93ea-bb65-4a55-ad49-f03bb7d95c88.prompt=UserName\: 2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.225d18a4-6990-4917-b97a-bc2611ebccc7.prompt=Enter a value for target 2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.32e1f542-3dae-4b1b-972f-5d5efa9b1ab2.prompt=Enter a value for target 2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.3d9e86fc-47b2-4cdf-a4d3-63bb4cd5492a.description=
Pings a host from a Solaris system.

Inputs\:
host - the host to perform the ping from.
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty (may mangle stdout and stderr if set to true)
username - username to connect as
password - password
privateKeyFile - The absolute path to the private key file for remote host.
command - DO NOT CHANGE
target - the host to ping.
packets - the number of packets to send to target.
packetSize - the size of packets to send to target.

Returns\:
the raw output of the ping command.

Extra Results\:
address - actual IP address pinged
% Packet Loss - The percentage of packets that ping replies were received for.
average latency - The average ping response time in milliseconds.
max latency - The maximum response time of all the pings (in milliseconds).
min latency - the minimum number of milliseconds it took to receive a ping response.

Responses\:
success - ping completed successfully.
diagnosed - target did not respond to ping.
failure - target could not be pinged.

2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.3e92875c-4820-4032-a30f-b96a6e656de1.prompt=Enter a value for target
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.44136f60-397e-4465-898c-94ccaf659be9.prompt=HostName\:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.4522cbdc-9b53-4c38-91cc-ff4452fa0e7f.prompt=Password\:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.4710f420-a68d-45b9-8a22-36dd7c33da3b.prompt=Password\:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.52b5fd5c-488c-4f87-b942-fe7b9f88efdd.prompt=Enter a value for target
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.6fca8d04-3080-44f4-8900-406a3223d63b.description=
Uses WMI to attempt to create a remote process on a machine.  The command passed should be formatted as though it was run on the command line.

CAUTION\: internally 'cmd /c' gets prepended to the command passed.  Also '2>tempfile 1>tempfile' get appended to the command so that we can attempt to capture stdout and stderr.
So your command will look like this when executed\:
	'cmd /c [your command] 2>temperr 1>tempout'

Input Parameters\:
host - hostname or ip address of the target machine
command - the command you want executed
user - alternate credentials username
password - alternate credentials password

Responses\:
success - remote process successfully launched and has completed executing
failure - unable to start remote process

Extra Results\:
ReturnValue - return value from WMI for starting the process (not the exit value of the process)
ProcessID - the process id of the remote process
StdOut - standard output from the remote process
StdErr - standard error from the remote process

Scriptlet Example\: (populates the Return Results with the output of the command)
$sErr \= %scriptletRawResult["StdErr"];
$sOut \= %scriptletRawResult["StdOut"];

if (strlen($sErr) gt 0)
{
   $scriptletResult \= $sErr;
   if ($sErr \!\= $sOut)
   {
      $scriptletResult \= $scriptletResult.$sOut;
   }
}
else
{
   $scriptletResult \= $sOut;
}


2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.734ed108-80b7-45e6-b6e9-553f31c31b0f.prompt=UserName\:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.8bc0c0c5-3a32-4f25-8f44-650164e98ba9.prompt=HostName\:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.8ef16773-4368-4fd3-8a5a-bd40d8a94cab.prompt=Enter a value for host
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.914163c2-2911-4d71-88d8-8530c8868791.prompt=HostName\:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.93c7385f-6a80-49ab-ac19-356ec15ab1f3.prompt=Enter the Target \:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.a9b3ef60-83e8-4145-a104-8b88e5d9aab5.description=


OS Detector Connects to a specified host, and determines what operating system the host is running.

It is important to note that the NRAS will try to impersonate the username/password provided rather then login to the remote
machine using that username/password.  If both the NRAS server and the server being rebooted are in the same domain then it
will work.  If, however, the NRAS server and the server to be restarted are in different domains then you must specify a local
account/password on the NRAS server which matches a local account on the target server.  If username/passwords match then
Windows uses "shadow" authentication to perform the operation.  The other option is to deploy another NRAS in the same domain
as the target server and use this NRAS instead.

Input Parameters\:
host - hostname to connect to.
username - username to use when connecting.
password - password to use when connecting.

Responses\:
failure - System could not determine remote hosts operating system.
linux - Remote host is running linux.
solaris - Remote host is running solaris.
unknown unix - Remote host appears to be unix based, but is an unknown variant.
windows xp - Remote host is a windows xp system.
windows 2003 server - Remote host is a windows 2003 server.
windows 2003 enterprise - remote host is running windows 2003 enterprise edition.
windows 2000 - remote host is running windows 2000.
unknown windows - Remote host is running an unknown version of windows.

Extra Results\:
		osName - the completely returned string of the OS name.
		version - the operating systems version.
		hostName - The host name the remote computer reports for itself.

The following results give more refined results about what version of windows is detected.
If a unix is being run, the following results are always set to 'false'
		enterprise - 'true' if the operating system is an enterprise edition
		server - 'true' if the operating system is a server edition
		professional - 'true' if the operating system is a professional edition.
		standard - 'true' if the operating system is a standard edition.


returns the output of a uname -a for unix based hosts, and the results of osName and version WMI queries for a windows host.






2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.d974bc31-734d-46a1-b36d-7ef074c22a68.prompt=Password\:
2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.description=
Pings the requested machine from a remote host

Input Parameters\:
host - hostname or IP address of the host to ping from.
username - The username to use to authenticate to host.
password - The password to use to authenticate to host.
target - The target server to ping.
packets - The number of packets to send to target.
packetSize - The size of packets to send to target.
outputPath - network accessible path used by the operation to store temporary files. If not specified it points to \\host\admin$\temp\'. If this     path is not accessible you should change it to use another share that the host local system account has write access to. By default, the path will have to be  changed on Windows 2000 systems

Responses\:
passed - a successful connection was made
failure - something went wrong
diagnosed - A problem was detected (ping not responded to, or dns lookup failed).

Extra Results\:
output - raw output of the results
address - actual IP address pinged
% Packet Loss - The percentage of packets that ping replies were received for.
average latency - The average ping response time in milliseconds.
max latency - The maximum response time of all the pings (in milliseconds).
min latency - the minimum number of milliseconds it took to receive a ping response.


2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.e18f0d6b-3288-40de-b2a8-63c2dcf3da07.description=
Pings a host from a Red Hat linux system.

Inputs\:
host - the host to perform the ping from.
pty - (true, false) whether to use pty (may mangle stdout and stderr if set to true)
username - username to connect as
password - password
privateKeyFile - The absolute path to the private key file for remote host.
command - DO NOT CHANGE
target - the host to ping.
packets - the number of packets to send to target.
packetSize - the size of packets to send to target.

Returns\:
the raw output of the ping command.

Extra Results\:
address - actual IP address pinged
% Packet Loss - The percentage of packets that ping replies were received for.
average latency - The average ping response time in milliseconds.
max latency - The maximum response time of all the pings (in milliseconds).
min latency - the minimum number of milliseconds it took to receive a ping response.

Responses\:
success - ping completed successfully.
diagnosed - target did not respond to ping.
failure - target could not be pinged.

2c5348f0-c3b2-4b13-be43-0af939bb78de.e5e62f46-a45d-4ad5-8fa8-2e15e88ba7f5.description=
Pings a host from a Red Hat linux system.

Inputs\:

pty - (true, false) whether to use pty (may mangle stdout and stderr if set to true)
username - username to connect as
password - password
privateKeyFile - The absolute path to the private key file for remote host.
command - DO NOT CHANGE
target - the host to ping.
packets - the number of packets to send to target.
packetSize - the size of packets to send to target.

Returns\:
the raw output of the ping command.

Extra Results\:
address - actual IP address pinged
% Packet Loss - The percentage of packets that ping replies were received for.
average latency - The average ping response time in milliseconds.
max latency - The maximum response time of all the pings (in milliseconds).
min latency - the minimum number of milliseconds it took to receive a ping response.

Responses\:
success - ping completed successfully.
diagnosed - target did not respond to ping.
failure - target could not be pinged.
flow.name: Remote Ping
